repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Environment and Natural
            Resources Sector Adjustment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and the
            institutional development impact was substantial. Lessons
            suggest that sectoral reforms, cannot be entirely effective
            without the accompanying investments, needed to support the
            transition into a new policy environment. In addition,
            substantial delays in project start-up, and implementation
            can be avoided if institutional capabilities - technical,
            financial, and administrative - are properly assessed, and
            an agreed action plan formulated with the involved
            institutions for focused capacity building interventions.
            Additionally, there is the need for communal responsibility
            in promoting sustainable natural resources management, as
            well as the critical need of community organization, to
            focus on building partnerships at the local levels.
            Communities need to be fully engaged in the process, and
            with proper capacity building measures to sustain their
            needs. Formal long-term tenurial agreements for the
            utilization of State lands, provide concrete incentives for
            farmers, and upland settlers to invest time, and capital, in
            ensuring high standards of land management. However, funds
            transfer mechanisms need to be set, for channeling national,
            and donor financial resources to the local government units,
            during the transition stage, prior to their full
            decentralization. Enforced legislation would curb
            environmental degradation, and deforestation.

728899.trustfund:
TF020760-AUSTRALIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST
            FUND - 0,TF020460-NORWEGIAN CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF027040-ENVIR. & NATURAL RESOURCES
            SECTOR ADJ.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Conservation of Priority
            Protected Areas Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Conservation of Priority Protected
            Areas Project consists of a sector adjustment program based
            on policy and institutional reforms, and an investment
            project in support of institutional strengthening and
            regional community-based resource management activities. The
            sector adjustment program will:  (a) determine what areas of
            the Philippines must be preserved undisturbed and introduce
            an effective management system; (b) impose user fees for
            public resources which discourage rent-seeking behavior; (c)
            improve enforcement of logging regulations; (d) provide
            secure tenure rights to users in return for sustainable
            resource use; (e) provide extension services to upland
            populations; and (f) establish mechanisms for support of
            community-based resource management and livelihood projects.
            The investment component will finance:  (a) the design of an
            integrated protected areas system; (b) program support for
            management of ten priority protected areas; (c) improved
            monitoring of logging operations and enforcement of forestry
            laws and regulations through the provision of equipment,
            training and technical assistance; (d) development in four
            regions of the capacity of local governments and line
            agencies to generate and service small-scale community-based
            resource management and livelihood projects in watershed
            areas, combining community organizing and pre-cooperatives
            development; resource management; introduction of
            sustainable means of livelihood and improvement in tenure.
